question: In humans, does infection with Helicobacter pylori increase the risk of gastric cancer compared with no infection? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: The estimated odds ratio for the risk of gastric cancer in those with a history of infection with H pylori was 2.77 (95% confidence interval 1.04 to 7.97, 2p = 0.039).
content.source_2: In a population-based case–control study using prediagnostic sera, a history of H pylori infection was not associated with subsequent gastric cancer (adjusted odds ratio 1.02, 95% CI 0.88–1.18; p=0.78), and sensitivity analyses excluding early cases yielded similar null estimates.
content.source_3: CONCLUSIONS H pylori infection may be an important cause of gastric cancer; between 35% and 55% of all cases may be associated with such an infection.
content.source_4: In a 15-year prospective cohort with repeated serology and comprehensive confounder adjustment, H pylori seropositivity failed to predict incident gastric carcinoma; the population attributable fraction was 0% (95% CI −3% to 5%), indicating the infection is not an important cause in this setting.
